sentence: Our study includes a total of 12,901 breast cancer patients and 12,583 controls (Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Fig. 1).

The association analysis, using logistic regression, was repeated with all controls and subgroups of cases, (1) estrogen receptor (ER) positive, (2) ER-negative, (3) human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) positive, (4) HER2-negative, (5) early-stage (stages 0 or I), and (6) late-stage (stage III or IV).Results
Ethnicity distribution in our study
A PC analysis (PCA) plot of genotyping data shows the distinction between the six major ethnicities present in our study (Fig. 1).
The same PCA plot, but colored by study, showed that the spread seen in the Chinese is due to the country of recruitment (Supplementary Fig. 1).

The majority of breast cancer cases were ER-positive (n = 8558, 66%), HER2-negative (n = 3777, 45%), and stage II (n = 4597, 36%) (Supplementary Table 1).Associations between SNPs and breast cancer risk
None of the associations between the 10,886 SNPs chromosome 6 (15–55 Mb) and breast cancer risk reached genome-wide significance (P < 5e−8) (Fig. 2A).
2B–E and Fig. 3).
Heatmap of the 71 classic 2-digits HLA alleles by study participants did not show obvious clustering of cases and controls (Supplementary Fig. 4).
Of the 175 HLA alleles, the association between HLA-C*12:03 and breast cancer risk attained the smallest p-value (OR = 1.29, P = 1.08e-3) (Fig. 2A).

No appreciable change was observed after adjustments for study and breast cancer risk factors (age, body mass index number of first-degree family members with breast cancer, number of children, age at menarche, menopausal status, oral contraceptive use, and hormone replacement therapy use) (Supplementary Fig. 5A and Supplementary Table 56).
Our study includes a total of 12,901 breast cancer patients and 12,583 controls (Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Fig. 1).

The association analysis, using logistic regression, was repeated with all controls and subgroups of cases, (1) estrogen receptor (ER) positive, (2) ER-negative, (3) human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) positive, (4) HER2-negative, (5) early-stage (stages 0 or I), and (6) late-stage (stage III or IV).Results

Our study includes a total of 12,901 breast cancer patients and 12,583 controls (Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Fig. 1).
Our study includes a total of 12,901 breast cancer patients and 12,583 controls (Supplementary Table 1 and Supplementary Fig. 1).

Results
Ethnicity distribution in our study
A PC analysis (PCA) plot of genotyping data shows the distinction between the six major ethnicities present in our study (Fig. 1).
The same PCA plot, but colored by study, showed that the spread seen in the Chinese is due to the country of recruitment (Supplementary Fig. 1).

The majority of breast cancer cases were ER-positive (n = 8558, 66%), HER2-negative (n = 3777, 45%), and stage II (n = 4597, 36%) (Supplementary Table 1).Associations between SNPs and breast cancer risk
None of the associations between the 10,886 SNPs chromosome 6 (15–55 Mb) and breast cancer risk reached genome-wide significance (P < 5e−8) (Fig. 2A).
2B–E and Fig. 3).
Heatmap of the 71 classic 2-digits HLA alleles by study participants did not show obvious clustering of cases and controls (Supplementary Fig. 4).
Of the 175 HLA alleles, the association between HLA-C*12:03 and breast cancer risk attained the smallest p-value (OR = 1.29, P = 1.08e-3) (Fig. 2A).

No appreciable change was observed after adjustments for study and breast cancer risk factors (age, body mass index number of first-degree family members with breast cancer, number of children, age at menarche, menopausal status, oral contraceptive use, and hormone replacement therapy use) (Supplementary Fig. 5A and Supplementary Table 56).

Ethnicity distribution in our study
A PC analysis (PCA) plot of genotyping data shows the distinction between the six major ethnicities present in our study (Fig. 1).
The same PCA plot, but colored by study, showed that the spread seen in the Chinese is due to the country of recruitment (Supplementary Fig. 1).
A PC analysis (PCA) plot of genotyping data shows the distinction between the six major ethnicities present in our study (Fig. 1).
The same PCA plot, but colored by study, showed that the spread seen in the Chinese is due to the country of recruitment (Supplementary Fig. 1).

Associations between SNPs and breast cancer risk
None of the associations between the 10,886 SNPs chromosome 6 (15–55 Mb) and breast cancer risk reached genome-wide significance (P < 5e−8) (Fig. 2A).
2B–E and Fig. 3).

2B–E and Fig. 3).
Heatmap of the 71 classic 2-digits HLA alleles by study participants did not show obvious clustering of cases and controls (Supplementary Fig. 4).
Of the 175 HLA alleles, the association between HLA-C*12:03 and breast cancer risk attained the smallest p-value (OR = 1.29, P = 1.08e-3) (Fig. 2A).

No appreciable change was observed after adjustments for study and breast cancer risk factors (age, body mass index number of first-degree family members with breast cancer, number of children, age at menarche, menopausal status, oral contraceptive use, and hormone replacement therapy use) (Supplementary Fig. 5A and Supplementary Table 56).

No appreciable change was observed after adjustments for study and breast cancer risk factors (age, body mass index number of first-degree family members with breast cancer, number of children, age at menarche, menopausal status, oral contraceptive use, and hormone replacement therapy use) (Supplementary Fig. 5A and Supplementary Table 56).
